How to Edit DLL Files: 13 Steps (with Pictures) - wikiHow

 Talk How to Edit DLL Files   
 This wikiHow teaches you how to open and edit your Windows computer's DLL files using Resource Hacker. Keep in mind that modifying DLL files can permanently damage your computer. 
 Steps Edit 
 Part One of Two: Opening DLL Files Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f0\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Download and install Resource Hacker.  You can find it at  http://www.angusj.com/resourcehacker/ . Resource Hacker allows you to open and view DLL files as text files.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e3\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-2-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e3\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-2-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Open Resource Hacker.  It resembles an orange "RH" icon.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-3-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-3-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Click  File .  This is in the top-left corner of the Resource Hacker window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9c\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-4-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9c\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-4-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Click  Open .  It's near the top of the drop-down menu.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-5-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-5-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Navigate to the folder in which your DLL file is located.  In most cases, the DLL files you'll want to edit will be located in the "System32" folder.
 You can navigate through the folders by first selecting the "This PC" folder from the left-hand pane, then double-clicking your hard drive's icon. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d0\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-6-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d0\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-6-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Click the DLL file.  This will select it.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ef\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-7.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ef\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-7.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Click  Open .  Doing so will open the DLL file in question. You'll see its folders appear in the left-hand pane of Resource Hacker, meaning you're ready to proceed with editing your DLL file.
 Advertisement 
 Part Two of Two: Editing and Saving Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f3\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-8.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f3\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-8.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Double-click one of the DLL's folders.  These appear in the left side of the Resource Hacker window.
 A folder entitled "PNG", "Bitmap", or "Icon"/"Icon group" stores the code for system images. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b4\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-9.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b4\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-9.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Click a binary tag.  Binary tags appear in the DLL file's folders; clicking one will display its contents in Resource Hacker's main window.
 Binary tags are typically formatted as "# : #" (for example, "1 : 1033" or "123 : 1033"). 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-10.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-10.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Change the text or image in the window.  This process will vary depending on your DLL file and the type of content in it.
 For example, opening a folder entitled "Icon Group" will allow you to change the appearance of a system icon by selecting a different icon with which to replace the original one. 
 Be extremely careful when editing DLL text, as a single misplaced letter can cause a DLL file to stop working. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/75\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-11.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-11.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/75\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-11.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Click the "Compile" button.  It's the green triangle above the main Resource Hacker window.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f2\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-12.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f2\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-12.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Click the "Save" button.  This option is the green floppy disk icon without "AS" written on it. Doing so will save your modified DLL file.
 If you wish to change the DLL file's name, you'll click the "AS" version instead. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8e\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-13.jpg\/v4-460px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8e\/Edit-DLL-Files-Step-13.jpg\/v4-760px-Edit-DLL-Files-Step-13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 6 
 Click  Yes  when prompted.  This will replace the old DLL file with your newly updated one.
 If you click the "Save As" option, you'll need to type in a new name and select a save location.

 Tips Edit 
 Due to their sensitive nature, DLL files cannot be opened or edited with a Windows process (e.g., Notepad). 
 0 
 Helpful? 
   0 
 Add 
 Warnings Edit 
 DLL files are incredibly sensitive system components. Don't edit DLL files unless you have the necessary experience to do so.
